review.title: Multimodal MRI brain tumor segmentation using random forests with features learned from fully convolutional neural network
review.abstract: In this paper, we propose a novel learning based method for automated segmenta-tion of brain tumor in multimodal MRI images. The machine learned features from fully convolutional neural network (FCN) and hand-designed texton fea-tures are used to classify the MRI image voxels. The score map with pixel-wise predictions is used as a feature map which is learned from multimodal MRI train-ing dataset using the FCN. The learned features are then applied to random for-ests to classify each MRI image voxel into normal brain tissues and different parts of tumor. The method was evaluated on BRATS 2013 challenge dataset. The results show that the application of the random forest classifier to multimodal MRI images using machine-learned features based on FCN and hand-designed features based on textons provides promising segmentations. The Dice overlap measure for automatic brain tumor segmentation against ground truth is 0.88, 080 and 0.73 for complete tumor, core and enhancing tumor, respectively.

sections.heading: 2 Method
sections.text: Our method consists of four main steps (pre-processing, FCN, text mapping and RF classification), shown in Fig. 1.

sections.heading: 2.1 Preprocessing
sections.text: First, we exclude the 1% highest and lowest intensity values for each image. Then, the intensities are normalized for each protocol by subtracting the average of the intensities of the image and dividing them by their standard deviation. In return, for each protocol, the histogram of each image is compared with that of the patient images selected for reference, and then the dynamic range of intensities is normalized linearly to the range [0, 1].

sections.heading: 2.2 Fully Convolutional Neural Network
sections.text: In this paper, we have adopted the FCN-8s architecture in [14] for segmentation of brain tumors in multimodal MRI images, using the VGG16 [15] as CNN classification network. In the FCN architecture, the classification network is first transformed into a fully revolutionary network, to which an upsampling or de-convolutional layer is then added to make pixel-by-pixel predictions. FCN training is an end-to-end supervised learning process and image segmentation is performed using a voxel-by-by-pixel prediction / classification. FCN-8s constructed from FCN-16s skip over the net and FCN-32s rough net. Predictions in flat layers are made using a skip layer, which combines rough predictions in deep layers to improve segmentation details. Specifically, in our experiment, the FCN-8s is then converted to the sum of two predictions on top of the 16x of the last layer of the prediction of the 16x of the prediction layer of the 16x of the last layer.

sections.heading: 2.4 RF classification
sections.text: Random Forests (RF) are among the most powerful classifiers [16] and are an interplay of several decision trees. Each node of a tree contains a set of training examples and a predictor. At each attribute split, a random subset of characteristics is selected, during which the RF is applied, based on the ROI recognized by the FCN. A confidence span of 10 voxels in the 3D space around the detected tumor area is selected by morphological dilatation. The optimal value for voxels in this target area is fed to the random forests for training. The most important parameters when designing RF are the number of trees, tree depth, and the number of attributes (catattribute) that are selected to perform the random split.
